questions.text: What is strategic networking vs casual networking?
options: Strategic is intentional relationship-building with specific goals; casual is random social connection
questions.explanation: Casual networking is attending events and collecting business cards randomly. Strategic networking is: (1) Identifying valuable connections aligned with your goals, (2) Researching them before meeting, (3) Offering value first, (4) Following up systematically, (5) Nurturing relationships long-term. Quality over quantity - 10 deep relationships beat 100 superficial ones.

questions.text: What is the 'give first' principle in networking?
options: Offering value, help, or connections before asking for anything in return
questions.explanation: Give first means leading with generosity: make introductions, share knowledge, offer help, provide resources - without expecting immediate return. This: (1) Builds goodwill, (2) Activates reciprocity, (3) Demonstrates value, (4) Differentiates you. Ask: 'How can I help?' not 'What can you do for me?' Most networkers only take; givers build powerful networks.

questions.text: What is the most important thing to do after meeting someone valuable?
options: Connect on all social media immediately
Follow up within 24-48 hours with personalized message referencing your conversation
Wait for them to reach out first
Add them to your spam list
questions.explanation: The fortune is in the follow-up. Within 24-48 hours: (1) Send personalized message referencing specific conversation points, (2) Offer promised value/introduction, (3) Suggest specific next step if appropriate, (4) Connect on LinkedIn with custom note. Most people never follow up. Those who do systematically build powerful networks. Use CRM to track relationships.

options: Someone with large network who generously makes valuable introductions between people
questions.explanation: Super-connectors (Scott Gerber) have: (1) Large, diverse networks, (2) Strong social capital, (3) Generosity in making introductions, (4) Reputation for valuable connections. Become one by: connecting people who should know each other, hosting events, being helpful, following up. Super-connectors attract opportunities because they create value for others.
